TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . Since DATE the applicant has been receiving an old - age pension . From CARDINAL DATE the amount of her pension was to be determined by the PERSON on Calculating and ORG ( the “ Pensions Law ” ) . LAW introduced a new method of upgrading retirement benefits—“Individual Pensioner Coefficient ” ( “ the ORG ” ) . The ORG , established for the purpose of calculating individual pensions , was the ratio between the individual ’s final wages at retirement and the national average wage , and was meant to maintain a link between a person ’s pension and previous earnings .

CARDINAL . The authority in charge of the applicant ’s pension — the ORG of LOC of GPE ( “ the Agency”)—decided that the ORG to be applied to her should be CARDINAL . The applicant considered this decision arbitrary as it conflicted , in her opinion , with LAW . On DATE she brought an action against the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) found in the applicant ’s favour . It held that since the defendant had misinterpreted LAW , the applicant ’s pension should be recalculated with an ORG of PERCENT . The ORG appealed against the judgment to ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) . It alleged that ORG had misinterpreted LAW .

CARDINAL . While the appeal was pending before ORG , on DATE the ORG requested ORG to re - consider its judgment of DATE due to discovery of new circumstances . The ORG claimed that on DATE ORG ( “ ORG ” ) had passed the Instruction on the Application of Limitations established by LAW ( “ the Instruction ” ) . The LAW specified how LAW should be applied . The ORG contended that since it had been unaware of these circumstances at the moment when the judgment was passed , the judgment should be re - considered .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG withdrew its application because the judgment of DATE had not by that moment come into force , having been appealed against to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment having agreed with the interpretation of the relevant laws given by ORG . The decision of ORG contained no reference to the ORG . The judgment of DATE accordingly came into force as from DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG submitted a new application for reconsideration of the judgment of DATE due to discovery of new circumstances . This time the ORG claimed , in addition , that on DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG had confirmed the lawfulness of the Instruction .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the ORG ’s application . The court applied LAW according to which judgments could be re - considered in case of discovery of significant circumstances which were not and could not have been known to the party concerned . The court found that the Instruction , as upheld by ORG , could serve as such a circumstance . No appeal lay against this decision .
CARDINAL . After a fresh examination on DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s claims in full having applied the ORG . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment on appeal .
CARDINAL . The Code of Civil Procedure of DATE ( “ CCivP ” ) in force at the material time :

“ The court of cassation instance shall verify the lawfulness and validity of the judgment of the first - instance court in the scope of the cassation appeal . It may examine new evidence and establish new facts . The court shall examine newly submitted evidence if it considers that the evidence could not have been submitted to the first - instance court ... ”
“ [ Judgments ] which have come into force may be re - considered on the basis of newly - discovered circumstances . The grounds for re - consideration ... shall be :
CARDINAL . significant circumstances which were not and could not have been known to the party who applies for re - consideration ; ...
CARDINAL . cancellation of a court [ judgment ] or of another authority ’s decision which served as legal basis for the [ judgment ] in question . ”
“ ... [ An application for re - consideration of a [ judgment ] due to discovery of new circumstances ] is to be made within DATE after the discovery of the circumstances . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed a complaint lodged by a number of individuals against the Instruction . ORG found that , contrary to the complaint , ORG had not trespassed its authority when it issued the ORG , and that the ORG ’s interpretation of LAW had been correct . On DATE the Cassation Section of ORG upheld this judgment on appeal .
